document.docAuthor: Butcher, Buntika Areekul, Smith, M. Alex, Sharkey, Mike J. & Quicke, Donald L. J.
document.docTitle: Aleiodes Butcher, Smith, Sharkey & Quicke, 2012, s.s.
document.masterDocTitle: A turbo-taxonomic study of Thai Aleiodes (Aleiodes) and Aleiodes (Arcaleiodes) (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Rogadinae) based largely on COI barcoded specimens, with rapid descriptions of 179 new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A turbo-taxonomic study of Thai Aleiodes (Aleiodes) and Aleiodes (Arcaleiodes) (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Rogadinae) based largely on COI barcoded specimens, with rapid descriptions of 179 new species

heading.emphasis:
Key to the
Aleiodes
(
Aleiodes
) and
Aleiodes ( Arcaleiodes )
species of Thailand

keyLead.key:
1 Hind trochantellus elongate, dorsal length at level where trochantellus most produced, more than 0.9 times maximum dorsal length of trochanter, and ventral (maximal) length more than 4 x posterior depth; hind coxa strongly transversely striate dorsally ( Fig. 3D ); fore wing 2 nd submarginal cell always short, with vein 3-SR less than 1.2 x length of vein r; hind wing subbasal cell densely and evenly setose; males sometimes with large, setose, lozenge-shaped pits on metasomal tergites 2 and 3; females with large granular appearing gap between widely separated placode sensillae on medioventral part of antenna ( Fig. 4D ); propodeum elongate and angular postero-laterally with posteriorly-directed tooth.....................................................................................
Heterogamus
(not treated here)

keyStep.key:
5 (4) Fore wing vein 1-CU1 0.6 x 2-CU1; subdiscal cell without longitudinal glabrous line subanteriorly; hind tibia white on basal 0.75, black apically (Fig. 194A); 3 rd metasomal tergite finely longituinally striate on basal 0.75 (Fig. 194F)........................................................................
A. ( Arcaleiodes ) vanachterbergi
sp. nov.

paragraph.keyLead:
- Fore wing vein 1-CU1 0.75 x 2-CU1; subdiscal cell with longitudinal glabrous line subanteriorly; hind tibia entirely orange ( Fig. 191A ); 3 rd metasomal tergite more strongly longitudinally striate on basal 0.5 ( Fig. 191E ).......................................................................................
A. ( Arcaleiodes ) dresdeni
sp. nov.

- Distal part of fore wing subbasal usually unmodified, rarely largely glabrous BUT never with sclerome; fore wing subdiscal cell usually evenly setose; males [for all those species for which it is known] without gland pore on tergites 4–6 ................................................................................................. 7

7 (6) Fore femur very robust, less than 3.7 x longer from distal part of trochantellus to apex, than maximally deep ( Figs 78A , 116A , 145C ); fore tarsus (excluding aroleum) very short, less than 0.75 x length of fore tibia, its median segment quadrate ( Fig. 145C )....................................................................................... 8

- Fore femur never so robust, always more than 4 x longer from distal part of trochantellus to apex, than maximally deep ( Fig. 121A ); fore tarsus (excluding aroleum) longer, more than 0.82 [minimally 0.85] x length of fore tibia ( Figs 15A , 22A ), its median segment approximately 2 x longer than wide or longer...................................... 11

8 (7) Hind basitarsus strongly laterally compressed and dorsally expanded medially in lateral view, inner face with dense long setae ( Fig. 3A ); size variable but up to 1cm long...................................................
Yelicones
1

- Hind basitarsus normal, more or less cylindrical, approximately 4.5 x longer than deep and not dorally swollen medially in profile; small insects with body length approximately 3.5mm [
Aleiodes
part]................................... 9

9 (8) Fore femur extremely robust, less than 2.5 x longer from distal part of trochantellus to apex, than maximally deep ( Fig. 78A ).........................................................................
A. globifemurus
sp. nov.

- Fore femur extremely robust, more than 3 x longer from distal part of trochantellus to apex, than maximally deep ( Figs 116A , 146C ).................................................................................... 10

11 (7) Fore wing vein 1-1A giving rise to a distinct, strongly reclivous, anal cross vein sub-medially ( Fig. 165B ); hind wing vein SR with a submedial angulation, usually giving rise to a distinct cross-vein r; fore wing 2 nd submarginal short and trapezoidal, vein 3-SR shorter than vein r ( Fig. 165A )...........................................
A. spurivena

- Fore wing vein 1-1A not giving rise to a distinct and strongly reclivous, anal vein medially ( Figs 106D , 127E ); hind wing vein SR without a submedial angulation and without cross-vein r and fore wing 2 nd submarginal more rectangular, vein 3- SR usually longer than vein r........................................................................ 12

12 (11) Distal part of fore wing subbasal cell glabrous ( Fig. 88G ); fore wing subdiscal cell evenly setose ( Fig. 88G ); distal part of fore wing vein M+CU and vein 1-CU1 strongly thickened near intersection with vein 1-M ( Fig. 88G ); largely bright yellow............................................................................
A . kitchingi
sp. nov.

- Distal part of fore wing subbasal cell usually evenly setose OR if glabrous THEN EITHER subdiscal cell largely glabrous (especially on anterior half) AND distal part of fore wing vein M+CU and vein 1-CU1 not strongly thickened near intersection with vein 1-M ( Fig. 96E ); colour variable.................................................... 13

13 (12) Basal 3 metasomal tergites forming a carapace with tergite 3 strongly curved in profile concealing all more distal tergites or virtually so AND postero-laterally emarginate ( Figs 32G,H , 59E,F , 181E,F ); mesosternum aciculate; hind coxa strongly transversely to obliquely sculptured basally; small wasps, body length < 4.5 mm .............................. 14

- Basal 3 metasomal tergites not forming a carapace concealing all more distal tergites OR IF more or less forming a carapace concealing subsequent tergites ( Fig. 52A ) THEN tergite 3 not posterolaterally emarginate; other characters variable......................................................................................... 16

14 (13) 3rd metasomal tergite approximately 1.2 x longer than 2 nd medially ( Fig. 32G , 59E ); metasoma tergites 2 and 3 at least cream-white laterally, and the 3 rd posteriorly ( Fig. 32H ); 3rd metasomal tergite with postero-lateral corner strongly produced ventrally ( Figs 32H , 59F ); hind wing with vein m-cu distinct ( Fig. 32F ).............................. 15

- 3rd metasomal tergite shorter than 2 nd medially ( Figs 181E ); metasoma tergites 2 and 3 entirely black; 3rd metasomal tergite with posterolateral corner hardly produced ventrally ( Fig. 181F ); hind wing without vein m-cu....
A. trisphaeropyx
sp. nov.

keyLead.keyStep:
15 (14) 1 st metasomal tergite dark posterolaterally, with paler area of variable extent posteromedially ( Figs 59E,F ); 2 nd metasomal tergites largely cream, dark anterolaterally; fore wing vein 3-SR 1.8–1.9 x 2-SR; lateral margin of syntergite when viewed laterally gently curving near level of 2 nd suture ( Fig. 59F ); occipital carina complete mediodorsally, more or less forming a point ( Fig. 59B ).................................................................
A. darlingtonia
sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
- 1 st metasomal tergite dark on anterior 0.8 with poterior margin cream coloured all way to lateral corners, with paler area of variable extent posteromedially ( Fig. 32G ); 2 nd metasomal tergites largely black except laterally; fore wing vein 3-SR 1.5 x
2-SR ( Fig. 32F ); lateral margin of syntergite when viewed laterally sharply angled at level of 2 nd suture ( Fig. 32H ); occipital arina broadly incomplete posteromedially ( Fig. 32C )................................
A. butcheri
sp. nov.

footnote.paragraph:
1. Included here because superficially very similar to the three new
Aleiodes
described in other half of couplet.

subSubSection.paragraph: 16 (13) Hind wing vein 2-SC+R transverse and inclivous ( Figs 29D , 87E ) AND relatively large insects with fore wing length> 6.5 mm AND distal part of fore wing subbasal cell largely glabrous ( Figs 29D , 87E ); fore wing uniformly yellow or with apical 0.7 dark, without clear apex; at least hind tarsus largely black ( Fig. 29A )................................ 17

- Hind wing vein 2-SC+R interstitial ( Figs 34D , 109C ) to longitudinal ( Figs 64D , 65E , 82G ) OR if transverse ( Figs 48A , 179E ) THEN smaller insects, less than 6.2 mm fore wing length OR apical part of fore wing subbasal cell largely setose and at most with a small glabrous oval shape surrounded by dense setosity; wing colour variable, sometimes with clear apex ( Fig. 159A ).................................................................................. 18

17 (16) Fore wing venation largely yellow except parastigma and immediately adjoining vein parts black, wing membrane entirely pale yellow-hyaline ( Fig. 29A )....................................................
A. bobwhartoni
sp. nov.

- Fore wing venation in distal 0.7 of wing dark brown, wing membrane entirely pale yellow-hyaline on basal third, grey on distal 0.7 ( Fig. 87A )..............................................................
A. jimwhitfieldi
sp. nov.

18 (16) Pronotum largely cream white with deep medial pronope usually bordered by a pair of carinate or subcarinate diverging ridges ( Figs 75D , 140C , 141D , 143A ); metasomal tergite 3 strongly curved in dorsal profile, punctate ( Figs 130G ); flagellum often with cream-white band, the flagellomeres in this part of the antenna with large, densely setose gap ventrally, devoid of longitudinal placode sensilla ( Figs. 4C ) [
Aleiodes coronarius
group 2 ]...................... 19

19 (18) Barcoding sequence known, molecular characters only.................................................... 20 Molecular data unknown, partial morphological key..................................................... 34
20 (19) Bases 1819–1821 coding for V; male antenna with only 1 to 4 apical black flagellomeres beyond white stripe........ 21
- Bases 1819–1821 coding for I; male antenna with more than 8 apical black flagellomeres........................ 23

23 (20) Bases 1549–1551 TTG coding for L, 1882–84 GCT coding for A, 1888–90 TTA coding for L...
A. concoronarius
sp. nov.
- Bases 1549–1551 GTA or GTG coding for V, 1882–84 coding for I, T or V, 1888–90 ATA or ATG coding for M..... 24
24 (23) Bases 1549–51 ATA or ATG coding for M; bases 1873–75 GTA, GTG or GTT coding for V..................... 25
- Bases 1549–51 GTA or GTG coding for V; bases 1873–75 ATT or ATC coding for I............................ 28

25 (24) Bases 1603–05 AGG coding for S; bases 1816 TTA coding for L...............................
A. deathi
sp. nov.
- Bases 1603–05 GGG coding for G; bases 1816 GTA or GTT coding for V.................................... 26
- Bases 1807 –09GTT coding for V; bases 1894–96 TTA coding for L; bases 1972 TTA coding for L................ 27

28 (24) Bases 1946–48 ATT coding for I; bases 1969–71 GCA coding for A.........................
A. pronopus
sp. nov.
- Bases 1946–48 GTT or GTC coding for V; bases 1969–71 GTA or GCA coding for V or G respecively............. 29

30 (29) Bases 1807–09 ACT coding for T; bases 1884–86 ATT coding for I.............................
A. cheni
sp. nov.

- Bases 1591–93 AGA coding for S; bases 1744 ATT coding for I; bases 1816–18 GTA coding for V.....
A. opus
sp. nov.

34 (19) Propodeum with well-developed posterolateral lobes, with indication of carina [irregular] up posterior edge of lobe ( Figs 15A , 60C ) AND lateral face of lobe coriaceous and distict from sculpture between it and spiracle; male antennae always with more than 8 black flagellomeres beyond white band.................................................. 35
- Propodeum more or less smoothly rounded in profile ( Figs 43A , 46C ) OR IF with some indication of posterolateral lobes

2. The
A. coronarius
group is one of the more challenging and while molecular data clearly sort them into putative species we have found no good characters to enable all species to be distinguished morphologically. Antennal coloration features appear useful but are sexually dimorphic in some species, and in at least two of the molecularly defined species, there some males show essentially the typical female pattern. Further, the great majority of specimens have one or both antennae broken at or around the white annellar region. Some of the damage looks like they have been bitten. The white zone also appears to have a glandular region of fine pores on one side in a large gap between the placoid sentillae. then lobe with coarse rugulose sculpure laterally continous with sculpture between lobe and spiracle ( Figs 11C , 43E ); male antenna variable, but sometimes with only 1–4 black flagellomeres beyond white band, or entirely black............ 36

35 (34) Propodeum dorsally almost straight with strongly squared posterolateral lobes ( Fig. 15A ).......
A. angulodeum
sp. nov.

- Propodeum dorsally distinctly curved in profile anteriorly ( Fig. 60C )............................
A. deathi
sp. nov.

36 (34) Prododeal sculpture above lateral propodeal carina when viewed laterally, appearing diagonally striate; male antenna with pale stripe occupying only 2 or 3 flagellomeres and separated from apex by at least 15 flagellomeres [pale stripe almost absent in one specimen seen]; female with mesoscutum largely black ( Fig. 46A ), male with dark marks on lateral lobes and anterior of middle lobe of mesoscutum ( Fig. 47D )....................................
A. concoronarius
sp. nov.

- Prododeal sculpture above lateral propodeal carina when viewed laterally, not appearing diagonally striate; male antenna with pale stripe variable but sometimes occupying more than 5 flagellomeres.................................. 37

37 (36) Hind coxa basolaterally rather coriaceous...............................................

- Antenna with white ring ( Fig. 11A ).................................................

43 (38) With lateral margin of mesoscutum and anterior of notaulus nearly black, middle lobe of mesoscutum entirely orange ( Fig. 143E ); midlongitudinal carina well developed on anterior 0.75 of propodeum ( Fig. 143E )....
A. propodocarinus
sp. nov.
- Anterior of mesoscutum entirely orange OR with only small dark marks on anterior of each lobe......... other species

45 (18) Hind coxa with transverse to oblique striation on most of basal half, at least on medial side when viewed oblique dorsal angle ( Figs 3C , 36F , 67E , 119B , 157G ) AND occipital carina complete ( Figs 36D , 189D ) and nearly always more or less forming a point mid-anteriorly ( Figs 67C , 119D , 173D ) AND mesopleuron and mesosternum ventrally never smooth and shiny between punctures ( Figs 36E )................................................................... 46

- Hind coxa more or less evenly coriaceous basally (basal to point of maximum width) especially on dorsal and dorsomedial face, not transversely to obliquely sculptured when viewed oblique dorsal angle ( Fig. 156A ), though sometimes pimples of aciculation may form parallel oblique lines ( Fig. 3B ), and posterior striation may extend along dorsal edge of dorso-lateral groove of coxa and sometimes more basally in some Chelonorogas group, but in these the mesopleuron and mesosternum are smooth and shiny between punctures; occipital carina variable............................... 66

- Antenna without white stripe ( Figs 105A , 157A ); back of head not black; apex of hind tibia with or without comb of setae; hind tarsus dark or same colour as hind tibia............................................................ 49

48 (47) Tarsal claws with 3 large, well-separated pecten spines; fore wing vein 2-CU1 2.2 times 1-CU1 ( Fig. 163F ); 3 rd metasomal tergite with midlongitudinal carina present (weakly) on basal 0.4 ( Fig. 163G ); antenna becoming pale between flagellomeres 16–20 ( Fig. 163A )......................................................... A. s ongsi sp. nov.

- Tarsal claws with pecten formed of line of many adpressed setae (see Fig. 2C ); fore wing vein 2-CU1 1.6 times 1-CU1; 3 rd metasomal tergite with without midlongitudinal carina ( Fig. 125G ); antenna becoming pale between flagellomeres 23–27 ( Fig. 125A )......................................................................
A. parasongsi
sp. nov.

50 (49) Claws with pecten of approximately 8 short, robust teeth that are longest near the middle of the line and diverge apically ( Fig. 114E ); metasomal tergites almost entirely black except for small ivory spots near mid posterior margins of tergites 1 and 2 ( Fig. 114G ).....................................................................
A. niveni
sp. nov.
- Claws without conspicuous pecten; metasoma not coloured as above........................................ 51

51 (50) Fore wing vein r approximately 0.5 x length of 3-SR ( Fig. 64D ); propodeum and metasomal tergites 1–3 cream medially, with bold black marks laterally ( Fig. 64E,F ); mesopleuron less strongly sculptured posteriorly, more or less aciculate to fine coriaceous posteriorly..........................................................
A. divergerus
sp. nov.

53 (52) 3 rd metasomal tergite distinctly curved dorsally in lateral profile ( Fig. 126F ), usually distinctly narrowing posteriorly from near midlength ( Fig. 126G ), basally finely longitudinally striate becoming acuculate rugulose on posterior third...... 54

54 (53) Speculum large, smooth and shiny; dorsal part of mesopleuron with rugulose sculpture; metasoma black with broad cream stripe along full length of tergite 2..............................................
A. rectanguliguttatus
sp. nov.

risaae
group)...................................................... 55

55 (54) Baso-lateral lobes of 1st metasomal tergite not angularly produced and usually weakly convex posteriorly, not projecting far beyond the small swelling associated with the spiracle though sometimes extending to spiracle ( Fig. 126G )..........................................................................................
A. parisaae
sp. nov.

- Baso-lateral flange of 1st metasomal tergite angularly produced and distinctly concave posteriorly and posterior margin of lobe nearly transverse or even reclivous, projecting far beyond the small swelling associated with the spiracle ( Figs 153F , 157I )........................................................................................... 56

56 (55) Body largely orange-red, head largely black except orbits narrowly red, metasomal tergites 3–5 black ( Fig. 157A ); CO1 without amino-acid deletion (codon at positions 2000–2002)..............................

sp. nov.

sp. nov.
].......................................................... 57

sp. nov.

footnote.paragraph:
3. The original illustration of
A. buzurae
from China shows a distinct hind wing vein m-cu is present.

4. Neither of the two species described as new here agrees well with the descriptions of the two species described under
Vietorogas
by Long & van Achterberg (2008) :
A. bachma Long & van Achterberg
comb. nov. has the 1 st discal cell strongly narrowed and
A. abditivus Long & van Achterberg
comb. nov. has the 1 st discal cell shorter.
